His losses, by sea and by land,</br>The merchant may weep and bewail;</br>Misfortune his terrors expand,</br>In varied complexion assail:</br>But let not Indifference smile,</br>On my sorrows, with Apathy's sneer,</br>When the Muse, in reciting her toil,</br>Shall draw from her poet a tear.

My bird has forsaken her nest,</br>Her eggs are all taken and gone;</br>The school-boy, her foe so profess'd,</br>This work of destruction has done.</br>Sly rogue, who committed this deed,</br>Might I thy correction command,</br>Unpity'd for this shouldst thou bleed</br>By thy master's inveterate hand.

For this thy week's pittance withheld,</br>Not a toy nor a tart should be thine;</br>To a task's triple length then compell'd,</br>And not till 'twas done shouldst thou dine.</br>I saw the poor hen with the dawn,</br>Collecting materials to build;</br>And heard the loud cock in the lawn,</br>As his notes in soft melody thrill'd.

The fabric was gradually rais'd,</br>Till compleat in the head of my bow'r;</br>How often with pleasure I've gaz'd,</br>And watch'd it from hour to hour!</br>But all my delight's at an end,</br>The truant has marr'd all my joy:</br>Had I seen the young caitiff ascend,</br>With purpose to rob and annoy,
Remonstrance, perhaps, were in vain,</br>His heart much too harden'd to melt;</br>But a discipline meet from my cane</br>The spoiler should surely have felt.

</br>Dear minstrel, fair architect, skill'd</br>The aerial structure to rear,</br>Again have you ventur'd to build,</br>My recent despondence to cheer?</br>How finish'd your work, and compleat,</br>So well intertwin'd and compress'd;</br>How snug and how round is your seat!</br>O what a most beautiful nest!

My hopes that in peace you may dwell,</br>Your eggs e'er in safety remain;</br>The filbert shall bower your cell,</br>And screen it from storms and from rain.</br>Thy partner's sweet warblings I hear;</br>Go teach him the orchard to shun;</br>The cherry so tempting to spare,</br>For fear of the merciless gun.

'Twas summer, in splendour array'd,</br>When I in the hawthorn espied,</br>Envelop'd amidst its calm shade,</br>A nest, of two blackbirds the pride:</br>Well nurtur'd by mutual care,</br>The younglings were ready to fly;</br>But Fate hover'd o'er the sad pair;</br>The sire was devoted to die.

He dar'd from the bough to purloin,</br>Where pendant the cherry display'd</br>Its rubies deliciously fine,</br>That crimson'd its relative shade.</br>From his post the sly fowler, unseen,</br>The poor plumy felon descry'd;</br>Nor was there a moment between,</br>E'er he flutter'd, he fell, and he dy'd.

No more from the spray pour'd his strain;</br>His poor widow'd mate was distress'd;</br>And, unable her brood to sustain,</br>They languish'd, and dy'd in the nest.</br>May no such misfortune attend</br>The theme that my muse now employs:</br>Myself their protector and friend,</br>Shall guard them from all that annoys.

From grimalkin's nocturnal patrole,</br>On ravage ferociously bent;</br>And truants, escap'd from control,</br>On mischievous errand intent:</br>And when to maturity brought,</br>Your offspring of plume and of song,</br>Their notes, by warm gratitude taught,</br>My praise in the shade shall prolong.
And farther I ask as a meed,</br>As Summer revolves in his round,</br>From care and calamity freed,</br>Their nests in my filberts be found.</br>
